Let A be any set. In this problem, we will see why mathematicians decided that is it "right" to say that \emptyset \subset A and A \subset A.
List all of the subsets of \{ 1 \}.
\emptyset, \{ 1 \}
List all of the subsets of \{ 1,2 \}.
\emptyset, \{ 1 \}, \{ 2 \} , \{ 1,2 \}
List all of the subsets of \{ 1,2,3 \}.
\emptyset, \{ 1 \}, \{ 2 \}, \{ 3 \}, \{ 1,2 \}, \{ 1,3 \} , \{ 2,3 \}, \{ 1,2,3 \}
Look at the pattern you see so far. Guess how many subsets are there of the set \{ 1,2,3,4 \}. How about the set \{ 1,2,3, \ldots , 10 \}?
\{ 1,2,3,4 \} has 2^4 subsets and \{ 1,2,3, \ldots , 10 \} has 2^{10} subsets.
Your answers in part (d) are very simple expressions. This is one reason why mathematicians defined "subset" to include the cases \emptyset \subset A and A \subset A. The power set of a set A is the set of all subsets of A. This power set is denoted \mathcal{P}(A). If |A|=n, what is | \mathcal{P}(A)|? (You do not have to prove your answer.)
If |A|=n then | \mathcal{P}(A)|=2^n

Prove the following distributive laws in two ways. First, using a Venn diagram, and then using a double inclusion proof.
A \cap (B \cup C) = (A \cap B) \cup (A \cap C)
This argument works backwards and forward. So this proves the double inclusion of these sets.
\begin{array}{rcl} x \in A \cap (B \cup C) &\Longleftrightarrow& x \in A \mbox{ AND } (x \in B \mbox{ OR } x \in C) \\ &\Longleftrightarrow& x \in A \cap B \mbox{ OR } x \in A \cap C \\ &\Longleftrightarrow& x \in (A \cap B) \cup ( A \cap C) \\ \end{array}
A \cup (B \cap C) = (A \cup B) \cap (A \cup C)
Once again, this argument works backwards and forward. So this proves the double inclusion of these sets.
\begin{array}{rcl} x \in A \cup (B \cap C) &\Longleftrightarrow& x \in A \mbox{ OR } ( x \in B \mbox{ AND } x \in C) \\ &\Longleftrightarrow& (x \in A \mbox{ OR } x \in B) \mbox{ AND } (x \in A \mbox{ OR } x \in C) \\ &\Longleftrightarrow& x \in (A \cup B) \cap (A \cup C) \end{array}
This argument does work, but it does have one subtlety. If x \notin A then each condition forces x to be an element of both B and C.
